Amid the chaos of Katrina and postponed Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Congress returned to session today.
Helping the victims of Hurricane Katrina is obviously at the top of the agenda, as are angry questions about the muddled federal response.
Earlier today, President Bush announced he will head an investigation into what happened.
The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee will also hold its own hearings according to a joint announcement today by Senators Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut and Susan Collins of Maine.
Senator Collins asked why the lessons learned after the September 11th attacks appear to have done little to mitigate this new tragedy.

How is it possible that almost four years to the day after the attacks on our country, with billions of dollars spent to improve our preparedness, that a major area of this nation was so ill-prepared to respond to a catastrophe?
There have also been a number of proposals to aid the recovery effort in various ways.
We're joined now from Capitol Hill by Representative Mark Foley, Republican of southern Florida.
He's no stranger to hurricane devastation; four touched down in his district last year.
Thanks so much for being with us today, Congressman.
Thank you.
Good to be with you.
Now you've introduced legislation to remove FEMA from the Department of Homeland Security.
How much support are you getting for that, and why introduce that legislation?
Well, we'll see how much support I get.

I've been asking for this effort for quite some time, even before the first hurricane struck Florida, because of my concerns was when we rapidly tried to create an agency to provide comfort and safety for America, I was worried that, in fact, we would have created the ultimate albatross, which is a colossal bureaucracy that has to report too many chains of command to get a simple decision made.

So I think in light of all the commentary on FEMA, on the response--and some blame needs to be shared by local and state governments, but at least at the moment, I believe separating FEMA, creating it and putting it back in the place it was to respond to these natural disasters would be a great step forward in trying to create, if you will, the agency that I think we all depend on and, frankly, we desperately need in these times of crisis.

Well, from your own experience with hurricanes in your state, what else do you think the federal government can do to be quicker in response to this kind of disaster, more effective on the ground and get there as soon as they're needed?
Well, I think it's preplanning.
And what I find regretful is that the local governments didn't do more to evacuate prior to the storm.

There's no question we've all known, particularly in Florida, that with the hurricane season upon us--Max Mayfield from NOAA, a national weather organization, have all predicted that this would be an extraordinarily active storm.
Jeb Bush, the governor of Florida, did what was right and ordered evacuations far in advance of the storm so that there was an orderly departure from homes.
That should be the norm, not the exception.
People were waiting too late to leave New Orleans despite the fact that it's long been known as a potential disaster area based on its location below sea level.
So I think there has to be a lot more preplanning.
Clearly, there has to be more resources in place and ready.
There has to be a greater coordination with the United States military, as evidenced by their rapid response once they were asked to join the effort.
They then were able to get the convoys in necessary to help remediate some of the crisis that was unfolding before our very eyes.
But the federal government does need to do more than just do modeling and planning.
FEMA says over the last several months, they've been studying the tsunami and its effect on the community and has an action plan ready for a comparable disaster.
Well, they may have done the test drill, but they failed miserably in the real-life exercise.
Now something else you've proposed is that you want to bring home National Guard troops from the affected areas, you want to bring them home from Iraq, is that correct?
That's right.
In this case, the MERS virus, we're not sure where it came from.
We're still trying to figure that out.
There's some evidence that it might have come from camels although we're still not really sure.

Six months ago we spoke with Dr. Joe Freeman, a physician in Baton Rouge who founded Free Life Medical Assistance for Louisiana to help patients get the medicine and supplies they needed to survive after the storm.
Immediately after Katrina, Dr. Freeman shared with us his frustrations.
I'm angry, I feel blessed that God allows me to do it.
I cannot have the same color skin as these people that you see on television that tell you that they have no water, they have no food.
If this where we were vacationing in Connecticut this summer, and where the complication of these people were not black, this would not be happening.
Last fall, Dr. Freeman opened two free clinics.
One was destroyed by Hurricane Rita.
But in Plaquemine, Louisiana along Railroad Avenue, Dr. Freeman's other office is still standing.
(Soundbite of train)
This is the Free Life Medical Clinic.
This was an office like I got in 1994 from a doctor.
This office was physically segregated, black and white.
And when I got it, obviously I tore the walls down.
(Soundbite of construction)
I don't know if you could see it, all of this was full with medications.
And again, in here, antibiotics, diabetic medications, formulas, everything you could think of.
So we have a lot of stuff that was donated from the people from across the country.

I had to strong-arm the pharmaceutical companies to give me plenty of samples, because I was writing samples and medications for those who had insurance, but those who didn't, particularly the elderly, they would leave here with grocery sacks full of medications.
So we are seeing people down here.
Wad a very difficult time getting it out that this was actually a free clinic.
We were combing the Medicaid offices, Medicare offices where we were seeing a lot of the evacuees.
Then read ahead: we're here, and then a week into this clinic, I became seriously ill and had several surgeries, and went through my own personal storm.
And at times, it was very difficult, because that at time, after Rita, the volunteerism kind of stopped.
And then we were not the hot topic, you know, but there was still a need, and there is still a need, a great need.
Although it was declared a state of emergency, we had a difficult time getting doctors credentialed to work in these clinics that I was in, because it wasn't a site deemed by FEMA as a disaster site.
I mean, I couldn't have that so we made a big ruckus, and someone came, from the government came out the next day and came, and I said--and finally, it was okay.
This site was okay now.
It was now declared a site, but it was always a hassle getting these doctors to come in.
They-I--for some reason, the state felt, from what I was told, that they can take care of it themselves.
Now, you look around x amount of months later.
What do you see?
They had a huge center that the, the Department of Health and Hospital at the Jimmy Swaggart Building.
And I see all these doctors who be coming in.
They're coming in from all over the country, walking around with their fanny packs and walking around the Jimmy Swaggart Building.
There were no patients at the Jimmy Swaggart building.
It was absolutely crazy.
They just didn't have it together, and they were not looking for the help to get it together.
Then, while I was recuperating, I was told about a FEMA clinic.

But I come to find out that--I thought was going to be taking care of people who were evacuees and so forth and so on, but it turns out that I was taking care of FEMA workers who were working at the morgue, and the Red Cross was there providing back rubs for the FEMA workers.

Now, that's good, but you know, I'm a little bit miffed because I was just told, maybe three or four weeks ago, that children are needing this and children are needing that--and now, I don't mind taking care of FEMA employees, they need help too when they get sick--but you would not believe the waste.
You would not believe what I saw.
Right now, it comes down to what are you going to do as a individual, and I get a call from Kaiser Permanente.
A group of people in Kaiser, Northern California, they are thinking about adopting this clinic.
So therefore, I will have the funds to hire the people, maybe hire a part-time displaced physician to help until, and if, we ever rebuild.

When a hurricane causes severe damage to a city, it often raises the question of whether people should've be living in the worst affected areas in the first place, and should they then be allowed to return?
For some in New York City, nearly two years after Hurricane Sandy, the answer to those questions is no. In Staten Island, the state is tearing hundreds of houses down.
Here's Matthew Schuerman of member station WNYC.
Without question.
That has been my request to the president.
And simply put, those men and women are deeply stressed about the unfolding disasters in their home.
For your listeners' benefit, they do have FOX and CNN telecast in Iraq, and our troops are watching things back home.

Those men and women who are deployed from the National Guard in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida are under a tremendous, tremendous emotional strain knowing that their children, their loved ones may be homeless; they may not even know the status of those family members.
And they could be a valuable resource to us back home helping clean, strengthen our community, protecting property, helping stop looters.

But I believe psychologically, they'll be be very little use to us in the theater in Iraq at this time, and out of compassion, we should bring them home and let them help both secure their homes, their families and, more importantly, help their communities rebuild.
One other question.
There was a whole slate of tax cuts about to come up in Congress.
What's the fate of those tax cuts now, would you say?
Well, some need to continue.
Capital gains tax reduction at 15 percent probably needs to continue to keep the economy vibrant.
This is going to take a horrific toll on our economy.
But I think any new taxes probably have to be postponed.
And I hope, frankly, we strike an agreement on the estate tax.
It doesn't mean full elimination, but it could mean a number that would mostly satisfy 90 percent of Americans.
We have a huge bill that is going to come due for these natural disasters.
We're talking housing, rebuilding of levees.

We're talking about a massive infrastructure restoration project that's not going to come cheap, and so we have to be very, very prudent and very careful as we're allocating dollars that we not go too quickly on tax relief right now.
We may be able to revisit that as we watch the economy carefully for signs of stress.

But for the moment, I think our priorities have to be, rather than wrestling with the other side of the aisle over tax relief, more importantly, finding ways to solve the human suffering that's occurring in these states.
All right.

Good to be with you.

Republican Congressman Mark Foley represents one of Florida's southern districts, and joined us by phone from Capitol Hill.
And you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And joining me now in the studio is Ron Elving, our--NPR's Washington editor.
Ron, thanks so much for being with us.
I wanted to continue this discussion about what's going on on Capitol Hill.
We just heard Congressman Foley say that some of the administration's agenda on tax cuts may have to be modified somewhat.
How is all this affecting the president's agenda on the Hill and what's going on on Capitol Hill now?
Lynn, the first thing that's happened is that no other subject is really of relevance, no other subject is going to get an individual member of Congress any attention.
Everybody is talking about this disaster that's overtaken the Gulf Coast region.
And all the other things that people were coming back here with a full head of steam to do or talk about or push or resist, it's all put to one side.

The only possible exception to that would be the nomination of John Roberts to the Supreme Court, and even that has been postponed into next week because, of course, of the death of the chief justice, William Rehnquist, and the decision by the president to nominate John Roberts to that job instead of to the other vacancy on the Supreme Court.
So we are still talking about the Supreme Court, but apart from that, all other issues basically in a cocked hat at this point.
Everyone is focusing on Katrina.

And when there's an issue like that, when there is a moment like that in the history of Congress, such as after 9/11, really it drives everything else off the agenda and lasts for weeks, months, possibly longer.
Now the president says that he is going to launch an investigation into the federal response; Congress--plans in Congress also for an investigation.
What will be the difference between these two investigations, would you say?
It's not clear what kind of an investigation the president has in mind.
When he made that remark this morning, he was responding to a question about creating an independent commission, such as the 9-11 Commission that investigated after the terrorist attacks.
The president resisted the creation of that commission several years ago and then relented.
He is again resisting the idea of needing an independent commission, saying in essence, `We're going to look into why the response was slow and inadequate, and I'm going to lead it myself.
So you don't really need to do anything else in the executive branch or outside the executive branch.'
